name: pre-oe-a-fronting
notes: The fronting to Ç£ is specific to West Saxon; Kentish and Anglian dialects had Ä instead (Ringe 2014:149)

name: oe-palatal-diphtongization
notes: This sound change is specific to West Saxon dialects

branches.comment: 'o' comes up only in synchronous contexts

name: oe-i-syncope-near-l
notes: Ringe 2014:276: the sound change responsible for these instances of syncope was arrested before it went to completion

name: oe-postconsonantal-j
notes: TODO: according to Ringe this applies only to results of syncope, but looks like 'j' actually disappeared in many more cases

name: oe-depalatalize-before-consonant
notes: This rule actually applies only to palatal stops brought into contact with a following consonant by syncope.

name: oe-back-umlaut
notes: This is the WS version of the rule. In Anglian dialects, 'i' was umlauted to 'io' before all consonants except velars, and before all consonants in Kentish (Ringe 2014:320). In non-WS dialects, back-umlaut of *e was triggered by both and u and operated across any intervening consonant, except that in Anglian dialects it was blocked by velars (Ringe 2014:325).

instructions.comment:
merger of Ã¦ and i as e in unstressed word-final and other inflectional syllables
Hogg 2011:6.48

branches.comment: Ringe 2014: 334: inherited Ã¦ adjacent to palatals eventually became i

name: oe-long-ae-retraction
notes: Ringe 2014:199: The stressed Ç£ existed only in West Saxon dialects at the time. The results of this sound change were mostly levelled out.

name: oe-diphthong-i-umlaut
notes: This is the West Saxon version of the rule.

name: oe-2pl-before-pron
notes: Used when the verb is immediately followed by 2nd person plural pronoun.

branches.comment: this is a purely orthographic convention
Ringe 2014:227: -Åj- in present stems of class II weak verbs was unrounded and shortened
